settings.heading: WHAT IS LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS SYSTEMIC?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Lupus Erythematosus Systemic (SLE) is the most common type of Lupus. Other types of Lupus include:

  • Cutaneous Lupus: This form of Lupus only affects the skin
  • Drug-induced Lupus: This form of Lupus is caused by certain types of prescription medications.
  • Neonatal Lupus: This is a form of Lupus that affects infants born from women who have Lupus. This condition is very rare.

settings.heading: WHEN IS LUPUS MOST LIKELY TO DEVELOP?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Lupus tends to develop between the age of 15 to 45 years old.

LUPUS SYMPTOMS:

  • Fatigue
  • Hair Loss
  • Fever
  • Joint pain, stiffness and swelling
  • Chest pain
  • Headaches and/or brain fog
  • Butterfly-shaped rash over the cheeks and bridge of the nose
  • Rashes on the body
  • Photosensitivity
  • Fingers and toes that turn white or blue when cold
  • Shortness of breath

settings.heading: WHAT CAUSES LUPUS?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Most often, the cause of Lupus is unknown making it an idiopathic disease.

However, those with a familial history of Lupus are more likely to develop it and occasionally Lupus can be triggered by environmental factors.

Some potential triggers of Lupus include sunlight, infections, and medications (such as blood pressure medications and antibiotics).

settings.heading: HOW DOES LUPUS AFFECT HAIR GROWTH?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Because Lupus tends to have inflammation of the skin and most commonly attacks the skin on the face and scalp, it does often impact hair growth and hair loss.

Prior to treatment, those with Lupus will often find that their hairline, eyebrows, and eyelashes will thin.

settings.heading: IS HAIR LOSS FROM LUPUS PERMANENT?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Most often, hair loss from Lupus is not permanent and hair will re-grow once your Lupus is treated. However, there are rare cases of permanent hair loss when lesions appear on the scalp and cause scarring.

settings.heading: ARE THERE TREATMENTS FOR LUPUS HAIR LOSS?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Yes, provided you do not have scar tissue, there are treatments available to help grow your hair back. Some of these treatments may need to be discussed with your doctor.

Once your Lupus has been treated by a doctor, you should avoid autoimmune response triggers, such as sunlight, to avoid inflammation which could target the face and scalp.

settings.heading: WHAT ELSE CAN I DO TO PREVENT HAIR LOSS WITH LUPUS?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
While the first step is always to treat the condition, after that you can do a number of things to help encourage and nurture your hair growth. Here are a few examples of things you could incorporate into your hair care routine:

  • Avoid environmental triggers for Lupus
  • Use a satin pillow case
  • Use hot oil treatments and/or hair masks
  • Limit the use of heat tools on your hair
  • Avoid hairstyles that pull on the root of your hair
  • Take supplements that support hair growth
